instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good‚Äù and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message:
Sadly I dont have that much troubleshooting experience yet. Have rebuilt some backlight circuits and repaired the common iPhone errors so that's something.

The board Im working on now 820 4924 stopped working because of liquid damage and didn't turn on but with a light on the charger. Got the board out and it took around 36mA. Got the first few G3H lines as normal so went ahead to clean up the dirty corroded areas:
<CHIP>U3740</CHIP>
<TRANSISTOR>Q5480</TRANSISTOR>
<TRANSISTOR>Q1840</TRANSISTOR>
<TRANSISTOR>Q1842</TRANSISTOR>

I first was confused by the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> being 12.5V for a macbook since I worked more on MBA's. Expected it to be 8.6V so looked around the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> and replaced it with a donor. PPBUS stayed the same and found out that the voltage is normal for the MBP's. Now it's starting around 44mA and working to 49-51mA after a few seconds. This after replacing the ISL and cleaning up. These are a few rails to get an idea:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.5
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> = 12.5
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.42
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER5V</SIGNAL> = 12.5
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER3V3</SIGNAL> = 12.5
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.32
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 3.32


<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5.0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.32
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 3.32

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S4_X239</SIGNAL> = 0

<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0_CPUVR</SIGNAL> = 12.53

Looking around the web I expected that an <SIGNAL>S4_EN</SIGNAL> signal is maybe missing since I couldn't find any shorts on the S4 rails which might cause all S4 rails to be pulled to ground. Trailing back some <SIGNAL>S4_EN</SIGNAL> signals gets me to big BGA chips. When it is not reaching an S4 state, what would be some of the first useful enable signals to check? Or is there something that Im overlooking right now?

Thanks in advance!

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Be sure to use original 60/85W Magsafe 2 charger; forget about 1 -> 2 adapter!

Post <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.

Also try to start in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message:
Thanks alot!

The values I found are:
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> = 37mV
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 3.34V
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> = 2.5V
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> = 3.0V
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> = 3.34V

When triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> goes to 0.36V

Looked up SMC bypass mode, suddenly it's alive! Does this mean that it looks fixable after all?

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> = 37mV
----------------------
Be sure to use original 60/85W Magsafe 2 charger; forget about 1 -> 2 adapter!"
???

Check if starts with both charger and battery connected.

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message:
I've snipped this magsafe 2 which came in the box of an 2013 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>. Now hooking it to a fully functioning an unsnipped 60W magsafe 2 and connecting the battery the device does not boot but has S0 rails. No chime no keyboard backlight or display backlight or display.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 5.13V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 3.32V
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 1.85V
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> = 1.5V

Cant find short so I think it's another simple thing I am overlooking. Fan is spinning but no questionmark folder.

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message:
"Fan is spinning"
In normal mode???
It should spin at max from the begining in SMC bypass; but fan only starts in normal mode when CPU gets really hot.
So, did you really start in normal mode?

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message:
It does not spin max, it only spins as if the CPU gets hot, so spins in normal mode and I did a start in normal mode.

I see that it probably spun because CPU got very hot. Trying it again now results in no fanspin at all. I do have Vcore. What is the thought process from here? Does the board need a battery to boot or is that a diagnostic trick? I remember reading old <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>'s need a battery to start.

So far I'm thinking: <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> -> <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> -> CHIME but not getting a chime :(

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message:
If you get VCORE, check <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>.
Also test for USB activity.

Try PRAM reset.

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3.32V
L4605 reads 5.13V when connecting a lightningcable with an iPhone, looks like this is normal

PRAM reset resulted in no chime no image flickering and no change as far as I can tell

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message:
I said test for USB "activity", no "power"; is a BIG difference.
Use a pendrive with Link LED; if flashes, activity is onfirmed...

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message: The link LED flashes, so there is activity! :)

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message:
So no image, no backlight at this point?
Caps Lock reacts?

Test external video too.

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message:
No capslock react, sadly dont have another known good 2013-2015 Pro keyboard to test atm. No backlight, no image. When connected to an external monitor the monitor recognizes the power of the source but no further data (TV sees a hdmi being used but does not give image).

Since USB data does work, does this work towards corrupt BIOS or more CPU issues? Or does the Vcore already rule out most if not all CPU issues?

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message:
I'm not sure if you really have USB activity.
If you connect preinstalled OSX into pendrive, does it flash like loading OSX?

Try full known good BIOS...

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message: oh sorry, the  flashiing was only power, but since it connected poorly it flashed twice which I read as activity instead of power. Got a pendrive with link led which does not flash :(

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message:
So no USB activity, as I was expecting.
Now try BIOS.

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message:
Yep Im on it! One question, since I am just starting out I dont have a BIOS programmer I saw you recommending the Medusa programmer on the forum. The first version supports until 2017 models. Any benefit to going for the series 3 instead of the 2?

How do I go about flashing the SPI when I dont have a programmer? Desoldering and then :S? Or is the medusa mandatory for these BIOS modifications?

Thank you for helping by the way!

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message:
Medusa allows to read/write BIOS onboard and time is money!

You can do the job with any BIOS programmer and correct adapter.
This imply lot of time and not easy job.
Without Medusa, you need to do any mods on the BIOS file by software, in another PC.

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message: Hi 2informaticos! I ordered the medusa and today it shipped right away. Meanwhile I was wondering if there are some videos on how to erase the current SPI ROM and how to write a full new BIOS to the chip. The manufacturer does not have many videos on that. Do you have any? I cannot seem to find any BIOS flashing videos of louis :(. Would like not to do it as trial and error since I heard plenty of horror stories about bricking a motherboard by installing the wrong BIOS or the right BIOS the wrong way.

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message:
Medusa comes with pdf manual.
You just need to connect it properly and move the switches according with the needed operation mode.

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message:
Medusa arrived together with a regular programmer

I've downloaded a full BIOS, made a backup of the current BIOS en flashed the fresh one. I let medusa clean the ME but still no activity on USB or Display.

I think I am also not sure about the Vcore. On this model I measure <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> which looks to be the CPU power in, is this the "Vcore"

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message:
Yes, <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is common power rail for core CPU and iGPU.
Did you verify Mac ROM against Medusa ROM after each read/write operation?


[ATTACH type="full" width="30%"]58387._xfImport[/ATTACH]

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message:
Yes I verfied it with two BIOSes right now. I can link them but don't know if that's allowed on the forum

Summary until now:
All S0 rails work as does Vcore (very nice and stable 1.85V)
Tried flashing two different bioses all verified and afterwards Cleaned by the Medusa
No USB activity nor any image on macbook-/external display (also tried with flashlight in case of no backlight.
Have the board only connected with the DCIN adapter, no battery nor fan connected (don't know if that makes a difference on that board)

Next up:
Buy a 85W charger to get amperage for further troubleshooting? (only have a 45W snipped hooked on my PS right now and using a fully functioning 60W version which is not snipped.
Check all S0 subrails for voltage and short? ("bruteforce searching" as I don't have any idea what could be the issue right now.)

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message:
Fan doesn't help to diagnose this board.
It only spins very late, when CPU gets really hot.

Test for USB activity on the onboard port.

This board should start with 60/85W Magsafe 2 charger, but not 45W one.

Didn't find clean ME (tested) BIOS posted on the forum?

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message:
Tested for USB activity on onboard port. My normal desktop gives a flashing red light.

Used a 60W and 85W charger
Used 4 BIOSes, cleaned all ME's through medusa and verified every step of the way and also checked if Vcore was present.
One of those 4 bioses was the only 820 4924 bios I could find on the forum which did not have an expired link. Sadly I could not find out if the BIOS was for a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A or non -A.

Also tested through MiniDP but the only response I got was that the port game power, no display visible.

Am I maybe missing the BIOS SN change? Should I change the SN of the flashed dump to correspond with the old SN?

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message:
No need to change serial number, untill get an working board.
Still no USB activity?

Try this BIOS...
[url]https://drive.google.com/open?id=1Hhdhd_t-9FxALozsa2067WnfRAUZqxNr[/url]

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message: Still no change sorry :(

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message: Is there anything else I can check? Maybe the SPI chip not communicating properly? Short on any S0 subrail? Or confirming dead CPU somehow?

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message:
Check all SPI Bus Termination resistors and traces.
Not too much else to check.
Could be damaged CPU this case...

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message: There was a broken trace between <RESISTOR>R6118</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R6130</RESISTOR>. Now it boots but with questionmarkfolder. Does not recognize SSD and does not give bootoptions when holding option key. Making a bootable Catalina drive, will update tomorrow!

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message:
Possibly no APFS support on BIOS.
A fresh install (internal SSD only) will update APFS support...

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message: OS on external HDD gives me this. First boots normally, but around a half filled loading bar it starts behaving like this and reboots after ~30 sec

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message:
That could be RAM, or CPU issue.
Be sure first to have good BIOS, clean ME.

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message: Used your BIOS and cleaned ME afterwards. Verified and all. After starting the ME changed which means the PCH has turned on. I can see some indication of waterdamage near the BIOS connector leading under the RAM heatshield. Any way to remove that thing? Since 500 celsius and 120L/min wont do.

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message:
Try another macOS installer?
What happens with internal SSD installation?
Start fresh install too...

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message: Wont start any MacOS recovery. Can choose wifi, but the loading bar after that does not got further than halfway.

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message: I talk about starting new installation on internal SSD from USB pendrive, not Internet recovery.

threads.title: 820 4924 taking 51 mA and not getting into S4 state
threads.message:
It finally worked! Took a while since I waited for a tool to make a backup of the SSD. Put Catalina on a pendrive and let it restore the os.

Thanks slot!

One last question. Why doesnt the online recovery method work (while giving weird screen distortions) when the pendrive way does work?
